images.summary: This plan provides the foundation, floor, and column layout for the farm storage shed. It includes dimensions such as 132'-0" and 81'-0" for the overall building footprint. The plan details the placement of concrete footings and columns, labeled as L1, L2, L3, L4, L5, and C1 to C4. It specifies a minimum of 6 inches of compacted granular 'A' on undisturbed soil. The plan also notes the inclusion of a roll-up door and stairs/guard/handrail as per OBC. Joists are specified as 2x10 at 16 inches on center with one row of bridging per span.

images.summary: This detail illustrates the top plate nailing for L1 and L2. The L1 nailing uses 8 nails as per plan, with 4-inch common spiral galvanized nails. The L2 nailing specifies 12 nails and includes a 24-inch scab. These details are crucial for ensuring the structural integrity of the top plate connections in the foundation plan.

images.summary: This detail shows the D2 typical truss to plate connection. It includes uplift ties or Simpson uplift clips for securing the truss. Shear blocks are placed under the truss between plates, and 4-inch common spiral 'Ardox' nails are used for fastening. The detail is essential for understanding the connection between trusses and plates in the wall framing.

It specifies a 2x6 or 2x8 scab matching the post depth, 18 inches long, secured with 26 - 3 1/2-inch common galvanized spiral nails. The connection includes PT posts and a double 2x6 corner brace, providing structural stability in the wall framing.

images.summary: This detail shows the wall framing for a structure, highlighting various components such as trusses, purlins, plates, and shear blocks. The trusses are to be installed as per engineered details and manufacturer's approved drawings. Purlins are placed according to the plan. The detail specifies the use of 2x6 ripped shear blocks under each truss between plates. Fastening instructions are provided as per BR1 and BR2 on page 2. Support plates and corner posts are also detailed, with vertical blocking and 2x4 wall strapping included. The detail emphasizes the structural integrity of the wall framing with specific components and fastening methods.

images.summary: This detail illustrates the BR2 brace to post connection, specifying the use of 2x4 strapping and either 2x6 or 2x8 scabs that match the post depth. The scabs are 18 inches long and are secured with 26 - 3½ inch common galvanized spiral nails. The detail also notes the use of PT posts as per the plan. The connection is reinforced with two nails in the strapping to brace, marked as typical. This detail ensures the stability and strength of the brace to post connection in the wall framing.

The elevations include a typical 10'-0" ridge vent. Dimensions are provided for the top of the plate at 16'-10" and the top of the floor at 3'-2". images.summary: This section view shows a roof truss system for a farm storage shed. The truss is engineered and spaced at 4'-0" on center, with 2x4 roof strapping at 2'-0" on center. The roof is covered with 29 GA. high tensile century rib steel. The section includes 2x6 wood fascia, vented steel soffit, and fascia trim. Ridge vents are specified as per OBC by others. Diagonal bracing is required on all webs needing lateral bracing, as referenced in detail D6. Uplift clips or fasteners are to be installed as per details D1 and D2. The contractor is responsible for providing stamped truss drawings for review.

images.summary: This transverse section of the farm storage shed, labeled as Cross Section A-A, illustrates the structural components from the foundation to the roof. The foundation includes a concrete wall with 3 rows of T&G 2x6 PT above a compacted granular 'A' base. The roof structure features engineered trusses with 2x4 roof strapping. Purlins are detailed with a typical splice shown in D5, requiring adjacent purlins at ridge and eave on each roof plane. The splice uses 22 ga. track and NIOHDG nails. The section also specifies uplift scabs for openings and notes the need for compacted soil preparation.

images.summary: This detail illustrates opening configurations with both wood and steel beams for the farm storage shed. The D3 detail shows a wood beam with engineered trusses, uplift clips, and 2x8 studs spaced at 16" on center. The PT post is full height with 1/2" galvanized bolts at 24" on center and 2 1/4" anchor bolts by openings. The D4 detail features a steel beam with a 1/4" plate fastened to the beam using staggered 1/2" bolts. A 3/8" steel plate is welded to the beam with 4 1/2" bolts. Both details specify the use of 3 rows of T&G 2x6 PT above the concrete foundation wall.

images.text_verbatim:
METAL TRACK CENTERED OVER PURLIN SPLICE
NOTE:
MAKE 2 ADJACENT RIDGE AND 2 ADJACENT EAVE PURLINS CONTINUOUS BY PROVIDING 4'-0" LONG 26 GAUGE TRACK AT EACH SPLICE LOCATION c/w (16)1½" 10d NAILS EACH SIDE OF SPLICE.
RIDGE AND EAVE PURLINS (SEE PLAN FOR NUMBER OF ROWS)
METAL TRACK AS PER NOTE
ALL PURLIN SPLICE LOCATIONS ARE CENTRE OF TRUSS
CONT. PURLIN DETAIL
images.summary: This detail shows a continuous purlin splice detail for the roof. The metal track is centered over the purlin splice, as indicated by the annotation 'METAL TRACK CENTERED OVER PURLIN SPLICE'. The note specifies that two adjacent ridge and two adjacent eave purlins should be made continuous by providing a 4'-0" long 26 gauge track at each splice location, complete with sixteen 1½" 10d nails on each side of the splice. The ridge and eave purlins are referenced to the plan for the number of rows. The metal track is applied as per the note, and all purlin splice locations are at the center of the truss. This detail is crucial for ensuring the structural integrity of the roof system by properly connecting the purlins.

images.text_verbatim:
RIDGE AND EAVE PURLINS (SEE PLAN FOR NUMBER OF ROWS)

The metal track is applied as per the note, ensuring that all purlin splice locations are at the center of the truss. This detail is essential for maintaining the structural continuity of the roof system by properly aligning and securing the purlins.

images.summary: This detail focuses on the continuous purlin splice for the roof. The metal track is centered over the purlin splice, as indicated by the text 'METAL TRACK CENTERED OVER PURLIN SPLICE'. The note specifies that two adjacent ridge and two adjacent eave purlins should be made continuous by providing a 4'-0" long 26 gauge track at each splice location, with sixteen 1½" 10d nails on each side of the splice. This detail is critical for ensuring the structural integrity and continuity of the roof system by properly connecting the purlins.

images.text_verbatim:
2x4 STRUT x 5'-0" LONG @ TOP & BOTTOM WITH TWO OF 3½" NAILS @ EACH TRUSS WEB MEMBER
ANCHOR 2x4 DIAGONAL BRACE TO LATERAL WITH FOUR OF 3½" NAILS @ INTERSECTION OF TRUSS WEB & TRUSS LATERAL
SPACING AS SPECIFIED BY BRACE DESIGNER 48'-0" MAXIMUM
2x4 DIAGONAL BRACING SPACED AS REQUIRED BY THE BRACING DESIGNER
TRUSS TOP CHORD
TRUSS WEB MEMBER
TRUSS BOTTOM CHORD
BUTT 2x4 LATERALS @ ALL SPLICE LOCATIONS. ENSURE BUTT JOINT IS TIGHT & CENTERED ON TRUSS WEB
LAP 2x4 DIAGONAL (MIN. 2 TRUSSES) TO ENSURE DIAGONAL BRACE EXTENDS COMPLETELY FROM TOP CHORD TO BOTTOM CHORD OF TRUSS (AS REQUIRED)
D6 DIAGONAL TRUSS BRACING DETAIL
images.summary: This detail illustrates the diagonal truss bracing for the roof. The 2x4 strut is specified to be 5'-0" long and is attached at the top and bottom with two 3½" nails at each truss web member. The 2x4 diagonal brace is anchored to the lateral with four 3½" nails at the intersection of the truss web and truss lateral. The spacing is specified by the brace designer with a maximum of 48'-0". The diagonal bracing is spaced as required by the bracing designer. The truss top chord, web member, and bottom chord are labeled. The 2x4 laterals are butted at all splice locations, ensuring the butt joint is tight and centered on the truss web. The 2x4 diagonal is lapped over a minimum of two trusses to ensure the diagonal brace extends completely from the top chord to the bottom chord of the truss, as required. This detail is crucial for providing lateral stability to the roof structure.

images.text_verbatim:
2x4 DIAGONAL "X" BRACE ON OPPOSITE SIDE OF TRUSS AT ENDWALLS & WHERE SPECIFIED ELSEWHERE
ANCHOR 2x4 DIAGONAL "X" BRACE ON OPPOSITE SIDE OF WEB WITH TWO OF 3½" NAILS @ EACH TRUSS
2x4 STRUT x 5'-0" LONG @ TOP & BOTTOM WITH TWO OF 3½" NAILS @ EACH TRUSS WEB MEMBER
ANCHOR DIAGONAL BRACE TO STRUT @ BOTH ENDS WITH FOUR 3½" NAILS
SPACING AS SPECIFIED BY BRACE DESIGNER 48'-0" MAXIMUM
2x4 DIAGONAL BRACING SPACED AS REQUIRED BY THE BRACING DESIGNER
BUTT 2x4 LATERALS @ ALL SPLICE LOCATIONS. ENSURE BUTT JOINT IS TIGHT & CENTERED ON TRUSS WEB
LAP 2x4 DIAGONAL (MIN. 2 TRUSSES) TO ENSURE DIAGONAL BRACE EXTENDS COMPLETELY FROM TOP CHORD TO BOTTOM CHORD OF TRUSS (AS REQUIRED)
D6 DIAGONAL TRUSS BRACING DETAIL
images.summary: This detail shows the diagonal truss bracing for the roof. A 2x4 diagonal "X" brace is placed on the opposite side of the truss at endwalls and where specified elsewhere. It is anchored with two 3½" nails at each truss. The 2x4 strut is 5'-0" long and attached at the top and bottom with two 3½" nails at each truss web member. The diagonal brace is anchored to the strut at both ends with four 3½" nails. The spacing is specified by the brace designer with a maximum of 48'-0". The diagonal bracing is spaced as required by the bracing designer. The 2x4 laterals are butted at all splice locations, ensuring the butt joint is tight and centered on the truss web. The 2x4 diagonal is lapped over a minimum of two trusses to ensure the diagonal brace extends completely from the top chord to the bottom chord of the truss, as required. This detail is essential for providing lateral stability and structural integrity to the roof system.
